column4: TABLE-Goldman leads AsiaPac Q1 ECM ranking; total deals up 18.4 pct
column5: March 31 Goldman Sachs led underwriting rankings in Asia ex-Japan equity capital markets (ECM) in the first quarter of 2015  preliminary data released by Thomson Reuters showed.      Total ECM deal volumes in the region's bourses rose 18.4 percent from the year-earlier quarter to $50 billion  according to data through March 27.     Proceeds from follow-on deals surged 37.1 percent to $38.7 billion  a record for the first quarter and helping more than offset a 19 percent drop in initi

column4: UPDATE 3-Units of Brazil's OAS file for bankruptcy protection amid scandal
column5: SAO PAULO  March 31 Brazilian engineering conglomerate Grupo OAS requested court protection from creditors for nine of its units on Tuesday as it grapples with fallout from a corruption scandal at state-controlled Petróleo Brasileiro SA  a major customer.

column4: UPDATE 1-Brazil's Petrobras will not sell distribution arm -board member
column5: SAO PAULO  March 31 Petrobras  Brazil's state-run oil company  will not sell its fuel distribution arm as part of its ongoing asset sale plan  company board member Silvio Sinedino said on Tuesday.

column4: Deals of the day- Mergers and acquisitions
column5: March 31 The following bids  mergers  acquisitions and disposals were reported by 2000 GMT on Tuesday:

column4: Brazil's Petrobras will not sell distribution arm -board member
column5: SAO PAULO  March 31 Brazil's state-run oil company Petroleo Brasileiro SA will not sell its distribution arm BR Distribuidora as part of its plan to sell assets to raise cash  company board member Silvio Sinedino said on YouTube on Tuesday.

column4: Prudential's departing CEO Thiam earned $17.5 million in 2014
column5: LONDON Prudential  paid outgoing chief executive Tidjane Thiam 11.8 million pounds ($17.45 million) in 2014  a 35 percent increase on his 2013 compensation  following a bumper incentive plan payout in his final year in charge.

column4: Quintiles  Quest to combine clinical trial lab operations
column5: Medical tests maker Quest Diagnostics Inc and contract research company Quintiles Transnational Holdings Inc said they were combining their clinical trial laboratory operations in a joint venture.

column4: UPDATE 1-Quintiles  Quest to combine clinical trial lab operations
column5: March 31 Medical tests maker Quest Diagnostics Inc and contract research company Quintiles Transnational Holdings Inc said they were combining their clinical trial laboratory operations in a joint venture.

column4: Tax breakthrough at Rio Tinto's Mongolia copper mine -source
column5: ULAN BATOR  March 31 Rio Tinto   and Mongolia have made a breakthrough in a tax dispute that has been among issues stalling development of the $6.5 billion Oyu Tolgoi copper mine  according to an official familiar with the government's position.

column4: SAP co-founder Klaus Tschira dies
column5: FRANKFURT Klaus Tschira  one of the co-founders of European software giant SAP  has died unexpectedly at the age of 74  his foundation said on Tuesday.

column4: SAP co-founder Klaus Tschira dies
column5: FRANKFURT  March 31 Klaus Tschira  one of the co-founders of European software giant SAP  has died unexpectedly at the age of 74  his foundation said on Tuesday.

column4: RadioShack co-branding of stores with Sprint wins court approval
column5: A plan to salvage RadioShack Corp's  business by co-branding most of its 1 740 surviving stores with cellular phone provider Sprint Corp earned U.S. bankruptcy court approval on Tuesday  ending four days of contested court hearings.

column4: UPDATE 1-RadioShack co-branding of stores with Sprint wins court approval
column5: March 31 A plan to salvage RadioShack Corp's  business by co-branding most of its 1 740 surviving stores with cellular phone provider Sprint Corp earned U.S. bankruptcy court approval on Tuesday  ending four days of contested court hearings.

column4: Sprint settles U.S. class-action lawsuit for $131 million
column5: Sprint Corp  has agreed to a $131 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit accusing the third-largest U.S. wireless carrier of defrauding investors about problems dating back to its $36 billion merger with Nextel Communications Inc in 2005.

column4: Sprint settles U.S. class-action lawsuit for $131 million
column5: Sprint Corp has agreed to a $131 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit accusing the third-largest U.S. wireless carrier of defrauding investors about problems dating back to its $36 billion merger with Nextel Communications Inc in 2005.

column4: UPDATE 2-Sprint settles U.S. class-action lawsuit for $131 million
column5: March 31 Sprint Corp has agreed to a $131 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit accusing the third-largest U.S. wireless carrier of defrauding investors about problems dating back to its $36 billion merger with Nextel Communications Inc in 2005.

column4: Sprint settles shareholder lawsuit for $131 mln
column5: March 31 Sprint Corp has agreed to a $131 million settlement of a lawsuit accusing it of defrauding shareholders by issuing false and misleading statements about its tightened credit standards  improvements in its subscriber base  and the success of its merger with Nextel Communications Inc.

column5: March 31 The following financial services industry appointments were announced on Tuesday. To inform us of other job changes  email moves@thomsonreuters.com.

column5: March 31 Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd

column4: UPDATE 2-Nippon says Ternium transferred shares before Usiminas vote
column5: RIO DE JANEIRO  March 30 Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal Corp said on Monday it had reported Ternium SA  to Brazil's CVM market regulator for transferring to third parties shares in steelmaker Usiminas  which they jointly control  before a vote to elect a new chairman next week.

column4: CANADA STOCKS-TSX set for lower open ahead of GDP data
column5: Stock futures pointed to a lower opening for Canada's main stock index on Tuesday ahead of monthly reading on economic growth for January.

column4: Vail Resorts buys Australia's largest mountain resort
column5: SYDNEY New York-listed Vail Resorts  on Tuesday said it would buy the largest mountain resort in Australia for $136 million  in its first international acquisition.

column4: Walmart CEO asks Arkansas governor to veto religion legislation
column5: The chief executive officer of Wal-Mart Stores Inc on Tuesday asked the governor of Arkansas to veto a religious freedom measure  saying the bill approved by lawmakers earlier in the day undermines "the spirit of inclusion" in the state.

column4: Wells Fargo gets U.S. approval to use internal models for capital
column5: WASHINGTON Wells Fargo won regulatory approval on Tuesday from federal banking regulators to use its own tailored risk models for determining its capital requirements.
